abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Vilnius Heat Demand
            Management Project for Lithuania were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            energy efficiency improvements in multi-apartment buildings
            of the Soviet era are a challenging undertaking that
            requires collective decision making by homeowners. It takes
            a concerted effort and a long-term partnership between the
            government and the private sector to successfully promote
            energy efficiency in these buildings. Key ingredients will
            be: information campaigns, support to Homeowners'
            Association (HOA) creation and access to preferential,
            long-tenor loans and/or subsidies. Under the Vilnius City
            Municipality (VCM) implemented components, the project has
            demonstrated a model of a municipal-level facility capable
            of operating in a commercially oriented fashion to finance
            residential energy efficiency. Creating the incentives for
            commercial banks to enter the scheme is the key to scaling
            up a program using such a facility. However, the project
            also demonstrated that building envelope investments remain
            costly, and energy savings alone may not be sufficient to
            generate a reasonable economic payback on them. For a
            national-level housing renovation program to be successful,
            it will be necessary to find ways to reduce the capital
            costs of building renovations.
